Twenty-two Countries: Caojucha, Bulitsishan Tangna, Andalaba, Kuoxituo, Huo, Mengjian, Anirini, Heluo Hu, Qilitsuoma, Balihe, Ximada, Butuochuona, Yinbojian, Quwangna, Damoxietieti, Shiqinini, Shangmi, Kebanluo, Wuzhai, Qisha, Zhuojia, Gusadana. Caojucha is over seven thousand li in circuit.
The country's capital city is called Heshena, over thirty li in circuit. Sometimes it is the capital of Hesaluo City, the city is over thirty li in circuit, both are strong and steep.
Mountains and rivers are hidden and secluded, fields and mounds are vast and open.

The crops are planted in season, and the winter wheat is abundant. The grass and trees are lush, and the flowers and fruits are luxuriant. It is suitable for saffron, and the plant known as rising grass grows here. The grass grows in the river of India.
In the city of Hasapura, the springs gush forth and flow, which the people of the country benefit from, using it to irrigate their fields.
The climate is cold and severe, with heavy frost and snow.
The people are light-hearted and impetuous, and their emotions are full of deceit.
They love learning and have many skills, and can recite tens of thousands of words a day without understanding them.
Their written language and spoken language are different from those of other countries.
They often engage in empty talk, and few accomplish anything substantial.
Although they worship hundreds of gods, they respect the Three Jewels.
There are hundreds of monasteries with more than ten thousand monks, all of whom study the teachings of the Mahayana.
The current king has pure faith, and for generations has upheld the succession, striving to create superior blessings, being quick-witted and fond of learning.

The rulers, ministers, and people of neighboring countries with different customs gather on auspicious days every year without appointment. Some bring rare treasures of gold and silver, while others offer domesticated animals such as cows and horses. They compete in making offerings and expressing their sincerity.
As a result, gold and silver cover the ground, and sheep and horses fill the valleys. No one dares to covet them, but only to make offerings.

They follow non-Buddhist paths and practice austerities with determination. The gods bestow their spells on them, and many non-Buddhists follow and practice them with considerable success in treating illnesses, often bringing about cures.
From here going north for more than five hundred li, I reached the country of Buluoshi Sandanuo.
The country of Buluoshi Sandanuo is more than two thousand li from east to west and more than one thousand li from south to north.
The capital city of the country is called Huobinna, which is over twenty li in circuit.

The climate is cold and harsh, and the people are fierce and violent.
The king is of Turkic descent, deeply believes in the Three Jewels, and respects learning and virtue.

From this country going northeast, crossing mountains and rivers, passing through several dozen border towns and small villages of the country of Kapisa, I reached the great snow mountains of the Brahmagiri range.
The mountain range is extremely steep, with perilous cliffs and precipices, winding paths, and hidden valleys.
Sometimes entering deep valleys, sometimes climbing high cliffs, even in the height of summer it is frozen, and one must break through the ice to cross.
Traveling for three days, one finally reaches the top of the range.
The cold wind is fierce, and snow accumulates in the valleys. Travelers passing through cannot stand still.
Even flying falcons soaring cannot cross over, but only after walking on foot can they then fly down and look at the other mountains as if at raised mounds.

The country of Andarab, the old territory of Tukhara, is over 3,000 li in circumference.
The capital city is 14-15 li in circumference.
There is no great ruler, and they are subject to the Tujue.
The mountains and hills are connected, and the fields and rivers are narrow.
The climate is cold and severe, with fierce winds and snow.
It is rich in grain and suitable for flowers and fruits.
The people are fierce and violent, and their customs lack organization.
They do not know about sin and blessings, and do not value learning. They only worship spirits, and few believe in Buddhism.
There are three monasteries with several dozen monks, but they all follow the Dharma of the MahÄsÄá¹ƒghika school.

The country of KhwÄlistÄn was formerly the land of TukhÄra.

The capital city is over ten li in circumference.
There is no great ruler, and they are subject to the Tujue.
The mountains are many, the valleys are narrow, and the wind is cold.
Grain is abundant, and flowers and fruits are plentiful.
The people are fierce and violent, and their customs lack moral principles.
There are three monasteries with few monks.
From here, going northwest, crossing mountains and valleys, passing through various cities, traveling for more than three hundred li, I reached the country of Hu.
The country of Hu is the old territory of the country of TukhÄra.

The land is flat, and crops are planted in a timely manner. Vegetation is luxuriant, and flowers and fruits are abundant.
The climate is mild and pleasant, and the customs are simple and honest.
The people are impetuous by nature and wear felt and hempen clothes.
Many believe in the Three Jewels, and few serve various gods.
There are over ten monasteries with several hundred monks, who practice both the Mahayana and Hinayana teachings.
The king is a Tujue who governs the small countries south of the Iron Gate. He moves his dwelling place and does not stay in one place.

The cliffs and peaks number in the hundreds, the valleys are secluded and dangerous, and they are always covered with ice and snow. The cold wind is fierce.
It produces a lot of onions, hence it is called the Onion Range;
It is also named after the verdant cliffs of the mountain.
Going east for more than a hundred li, one reaches the country of Mengjian.
The country of Mengjian is the old territory of the country of TukhÄra.

The country of Arni is the old territory of the country of TukhÄra.

From the country of Mangana, going east across steep mountain ranges, through deep valleys, passing through several river cities, traveling for more than 300 li, one reaches the country of Kuluta.
The country of Kuluta is the old territory of TukhÄra.
It is over 10 li from east to west and over 300 li from south to north.

Going east from the country of KulÅ«ta, crossing mountains and valleys for over 300 li, one reaches the country of Himatala.

The woman's headdress is made of wood, over three feet high, with two branches in front, representing her husband's parents;

Neighboring the Turks, they eventually adopted their customs. Moreover, they were invaded and plundered, guarding their territory themselves. To the west it borders the country of Khotan.
Going east through the valley for more than 200 li, I reached the country of Patali.
The country of Patali was formerly the land of Tukhara.
It is over 2,000 li in circumference.
The capital city is located on a mountain cliff, with a circumference of six or seven li.
The mountains and rivers are winding, and sand and stones cover the ground.
The land is suitable for beans and wheat, and there are many jujubes, walnuts, pears, crabapples, and other fruits.
The climate is cold and severe, and the people are fierce by nature.
They have no etiquette or laws, and do not know about learning and the arts.
Their appearance is ugly, and they mostly wear felt and hemp clothes.
There are three or four monasteries with few monks.
The king is of a simple and honest nature and deeply believes in the Three Jewels.
From here, going southeast for more than two hundred li in the mountains and valleys, I reached the country of Yinpugjian.
The country of Yinpugjian is the old territory of the country of TukhÄra.
It is over one thousand li in circuit.
The capital city is over ten li in circuit.
The mountains and ridges are connected, and the rivers and fields are narrow.
The land produces the same things, the climate is the same, and the differences in human nature are the same as in the country of Batna, but the language is slightly different.
The king is cruel and violent, and does not understand good and evil.
Going southeast from here, crossing over mountains and valleys, along dangerous paths, for more than three hundred li, I reached the country of Kustana.
The country of Kustana is the old territory of the country of Tukhara.
It is over two thousand li in circumference.
The land, mountains and rivers, climate and seasons are the same as in the country of Yumbujian.
The customs lack moral standards, and the nature of the people is vulgar and violent.
Many do not engage in meritorious deeds, and few believe in Buddhism.
Their appearance is ugly and shabby, and they mostly wear felt and hempen clothes.
There is a mountain cliff where gold ore is frequently found, and it is obtained by cutting and splitting the rocks.

Going northeast from here, climbing mountains and entering valleys, the road is difficult and dangerous, for more than five hundred li, I reached the country of Damoxielidi (also called Zhenqian, also called Huomi).
The country of Damositie is between two mountains, an old territory of Tukhara.
It is over 1,500 li from east to west and 4-5 li wide from south to north, and at its narrowest it is less than 1 li wide.
Facing the Oxus River, it winds and twists, with hills rising and falling, sand and stones flowing everywhere, and a cold and fierce wind.
Only wheat and beans are planted, with few trees and little flowers and fruit.
It produces good horses, whose bodies are small but can endure long journeys.
The customs lack propriety and righteousness, and the people are savage and violent.
Their appearance is ugly, and they wear felt and hemp clothes.
Their eyes are mostly blue-green, different from those of other countries.
There are over ten monasteries with few monks.
The city of Hontuo is the capital of the country.
In the middle is a monastery built by a former king of this country, with buildings constructed on a slope facing a valley.
Before this country was influenced by Buddhism, they only worshipped evil spirits. Several hundred years ago, the Dharma was first propagated here.
At first, the king of this country loved his son, but the child fell ill. Despite exhausting medical techniques, there was no improvement.
The king then went to the temple himself, made offerings, and prayed for help.
At that time, the temple master spoke on behalf of the deity:
The child will certainly recover, there is no other concern.
Hearing this, the king was overjoyed and returned home.
On the way, he encountered a monk whose appearance and demeanor were admirable. Startled by his appearance, the king asked where he was going.
This monk had already attained the holy fruit and wished to spread the Buddha's teachings, so he took on this appearance.
He replied to the king:
I am a disciple of the TathÄgata, a so-called bhiká¹£u.
Since the king was worried, he first asked:
My son has fallen ill, and his life is uncertain.
The monk said:

The king said:
The celestial spirits say he will not die, while the Å›ramaá¹‡a says he will die. The words of these worldly people, how can they be trusted?
Later, when he arrived at the palace, his beloved son had already died.
He concealed the fact of his son's death and asked the spirit master again, who still said:
He will not die, his illness will be cured.
The king then became angry and bound the spirit master, scolding him:
You all gather together and do evil for a long time, falsely practicing authority and blessings.
My son has already died, yet you still say he will be cured. This is a false and confusing deception, how can it be tolerated?
You should be executed, and the spirit temple destroyed.

He turned his carriage and returned, and again encountered the Å›ramaá¹‡a. Seeing him, he respectfully delighted, bowed his head and apologized, saying:

The Å›ramaá¹‡a accepted the invitation and followed him to the inner palace.
After burying his son, he said to the Å›ramaá¹‡a:
The human world is in chaos, and life and death revolve. When my son was sick, I asked about his departure and stay, and the spirit spoke falsely, saying he would certainly recover.
I first received your instruction and it was indeed not an empty statement. This Dharma can be followed. Please have compassion and guide this confused disciple.
He then invited the Å›ramaá¹‡a to measure the site for the monastery, and according to his instructions, it was established.
Since then, Buddhism has flourished.
Therefore, the vihÄra in the monastery was built by the arhat.
In the great vihÄra of the monastery, there is a stone Buddha image, above which hangs a golden bronze circular canopy adorned with various jewels.
When people circumambulate, the canopy also turns. When people stop, the canopy stops. No one can fathom its spiritual manifestation.
Hearing from the elders, it is said:
Some say it is sustained by the vows of sages, others say it is due to secret techniques of machinery.
Observing its halls and stone walls, they are solid and steep.
Examining the various opinions, the true record is unknown.
Crossing this country's great mountains to the north, it reaches the country of Shiqini.
The country of Shiqini is over 2,000 li in circumference.
The capital city is 5-6 li in circumference.
Mountains and rivers are connected, with sand and stones covering the fields.
There are many barley fields, few grain crops, sparse forests and trees, and few flowers and fruits.
The climate is bitterly cold, the customs are rough and brave, they are cruel in killing, diligent in theft, do not know propriety and righteousness, and do not distinguish good from evil.
They are confused about future misfortune and blessings, and fear present calamities and disasters.
Their appearance is ugly, and they wear leather and hemp clothes.
The written language is the same as that of the country of TukhÄra, but the spoken language is different.
Crossing the great mountains south of the country of Dashizhide, it reaches the country of Shangmi.
The country of Samarkand is 2,560 li in circumference.
Mountains and rivers alternate, with hills and mounds high and low.
All grains are grown, with abundant beans and wheat, and plenty of pine trees. It produces realgar, which is obtained by digging into the cliffs and splitting the rocks.
The mountain god is violent and evil, often causing disasters. After making sacrifices to it, one can enter peacefully and travel back and forth safely.
If one does not pray to it, wind and hail will rage.
The climate is cold, and the customs are harsh.
The people are simple and honest, and their customs lack propriety and righteousness. Their wisdom and strategy are narrow, and their skills and abilities are shallow.
Their written language is the same as that of Tukhara, but their spoken language is different.
Most people wear felt and hemp clothes.
Their king is of the ÅšÄkya clan and reveres the Buddha's teachings. The people of the country follow his example and are all sincerely faithful.

Crossing mountains and valleys, going over precipices and along dangerous paths for more than seven hundred li to the northeast of the country, he reached the Pamir Valley.
It is more than a thousand li from east to west and more than a hundred li from south to north, and in the narrowest places it is less than ten li wide.
Situated between the two snow mountains, the cold wind is fierce, with flying snow in spring and summer, and a blowing wind day and night.
The land is salty and has many pebbles and stones, and planting is not productive, with few grasses and trees, so it is desolate and uninhabited.

In the Pamir Valley there is a large dragon lake, more than three hundred li from east to west and more than fifty li from south to north, situated inside the Great Pamir Range, which is the highest place on JambudvÄ«pa.
The water is clear and bright like a mirror, with an unknown depth, and has a bluish-black color with a very sweet taste.

Those that dwell in the depths are sharks, dragons, fish, turtles, alligators, tortoises, and snakes, while those that float on the surface are mandarin ducks, geese, swans, and various birds. The eggs of these birds are abandoned in the wilderness, either in the grass and marshes or on sandbars.

To the west of the lake, a large stream flows west to the eastern border of the country of DÄmali, where it joins the BÄhudÄ River and flows west. Therefore, to the right of this point, the water flows west.

From here, in the middle of the valley, southeast, climbing mountains and traversing dangerous paths, there are no villages along the way, only much ice and snow.
Traveling for more than five hundred li, one reaches the country of Kuvana.
The country of Kapitha is over 2,000 li in circumference.
The capital city is built on a large rocky ridge, with the Sita River at its back, and is over 20 li in circumference.
The mountains and ridges are connected, and the valleys and plains are narrow.
Grain is scarce, while beans and wheat are abundant. Forests and trees are sparse, and flowers and fruits are few.
The plains and hills are deserted, and the cities and towns are desolate.
The customs lack propriety and righteousness, and the people are generally uneducated.
They are by nature fierce and violent, but also strong and brave.
Their appearance is ugly and haggard, and they wear felt and hemp clothing.

However, they are pure and faithful, and revere and uphold the Buddha Dharma.
There are over ten monasteries with more than five hundred monks, who study the teachings of the Hinayana school of existence.
The current king is simple and honest, and respects the Three Jewels. He has a leisurely demeanor and is devoted to learning.
It has been many years since the establishment of the country.
He claimed to be the descendant of the Indian king Tishya.
This country was originally a deserted river in the middle of the Pamir Mountains.

In the past, the king of Persia married a Chinese woman and brought her back to this place. At that time, there was a military disturbance, and the roads to the east and west were cut off. The king's daughter was then placed on a solitary peak, extremely steep, with ladders going up and down the cliffs. Guards were set up to patrol day and night.
After three months, the bandits finally calmed down. The king wanted to return home, but the princess was already pregnant.
The envoys were frightened and said to their companions:
The king ordered us to welcome his wife, but we encountered this military disturbance. We camped in the deserted river, not knowing what would happen from one day to the next.
Our king's virtue moved heaven, and the evil atmosphere has already calmed down. Now we are about to return to the country, but the king's wife is pregnant.
We are worried about this, not knowing what will happen. We should find the chief culprit and punish him later.
They questioned and argued, but could not find out the truth.
The attendant said to the envoy:
Do not blame each other, it is a divine arrangement.
Every day at noon, a man rides a horse from the sun and meets here.
The envoy said:
If that is so, how can we atone for our crime?
If we return, we will surely be executed. If we stay, they will come to attack us. What should we do in this dilemma?
They all said:
This matter is not trivial, who would accept a deep punishment?
We will wait for punishment outside the border, and postpone it for the time being.
Then they built a palace and a hall on the top of the stone peak, covering an area of over three hundred steps.
They surrounded the palace with a city wall, established a woman as the ruler, and set up officials to promulgate the constitution.
When the time came, she gave birth to a son with a handsome appearance.
The mother took charge of state affairs, and the son assumed the title of the supreme ruler.

They flew through the sky, controlling the wind and clouds. Their majestic virtue extended far and wide, and their reputation and teachings spread far and wide. Neighboring regions and foreign countries all acknowledged their supremacy.
When the king died, he was buried in a stone chamber in a large mountain over 100 li southeast of the city.
His corpse is still intact, looking like a lean person, as if asleep. Clothes are changed for him from time to time, and incense and flowers are always placed there.
His descendants have continued to this day.
Because in his ancestor's time, his mother was a person from China and his father was of the Sun-Heaven race, he called himself a descendant of the Chinese Sun-Heaven race.
However, the royal family has a similar appearance to the people of China, wearing square caps on their heads and Hu clothing on their bodies.
Later, the royal lineage declined and was oppressed by powerful neighboring countries.

Later, the king moved to the northeast corner of the palace, and the old palace was turned into a monastery for Venerable Saá¹ƒghabhadra. The terraces and pavilions were lofty and spacious, and the Buddha's image was majestic.

Going southeast from the city for more than 300 li, we reach a large rocky cliff with two stone chambers, each housing an arhat who has entered the concentration of cessation.

Sitting upright, it is difficult to move them. Their appearance is like a emaciated person, and their skin and bones have not decayed for more than 700 years. Their beard and hair always grow long, so the monks shave their heads and change their clothes every year.
To the northeast of the great cliff, crossing a mountain pass and traversing dangerous paths for more than 200 li, we reach PanzhÄrÄ (meaning house of blessings in Chinese).

Although the weather is hot, there are often wind and snow. As soon as human caravans enter, clouds and fog rise. Travelers come and go, suffering from this hardship.
I heard from the elders:
In the past, there were merchants with more than ten thousand people and several thousand camels carrying goods for profit. They encountered wind and snow, and both people and animals perished.

At that time, there was a great arhat in the country of Kimpunda who observed this from afar. He felt pity for their perilous situation and wanted to use his spiritual powers to rescue them from drowning.
When he arrived here, the merchants had already perished.

Then he collected all the precious treasures and gathered everything they had. He built a guesthouse and stored up wealth. He bought land in neighboring countries and sold houses in border cities to provide for those who came and went.
Therefore, travelers and merchants all received assistance.

Going down from here to the east of the Pamirs, climbing dangerous peaks, crossing deep valleys, the paths are perilous and obstructed, with wind and snow following one after another. Traveling for more than eight hundred li, one exits the Pamirs and reaches the country of UtrÄra.
The country of UtrÄra is over a thousand li in circumference.

However, they are able to deeply believe in and respectfully uphold the Buddha Dharma.
There are more than ten monasteries with less than a thousand monks, who study the teachings of the Hinayana school of the Sarvastivadins.
For several hundred years, the royal lineage has been extinct, and there is no separate ruler, and they are subject to the country of Khotan.
More than two hundred li west of the city, there is a great mountain.
The mountain air is misty, and the rocks give rise to clouds. The cliffs are steep and rugged, about to collapse but not yet fallen.
